The real question here is: how does this feature improve the game as a whole? To me it seems like another pointless goal for players to work towards, giving people the illusion of accomplishment. 

It also may cause insta-locking, with players joining games for the sole purpose of leveling a specific champion, rather than picking one that compliments the team make-up.

I think a better system would be creating a set of challenges for each champion. Ones that drive players towards fulfilling team goals, e.g for support characters you could have challenges for assists per match, wards placed, allies healed etc. For junglers you could have challenges for dragon domination, smites that result in kills etc.

So, in your better system, the jungler goes for every dragon regardless of feeding, then saves every smite for a player. Your support spends more money on dropping random wards and more mana on healing full health adcs than doing anything actually relevant (not to mention how to differentiate between healing supports and non-healing supports in a feasible manner), all in the name of stats. How, in your logical interpretation of a "better" system, is this in any way beneficial?

Rather than complicating things further by giving set goals that will be attempted to be completed within the smallest number of games, they have given a very generic objective, level a champion (which mind you, is affected by your ACTUAL performance, if you're just instalocking and feeding, it will take much longer). Will instalocking Annie support regardless of matchup be worse than a Soraka that heals full health champs to gain a few more xp towards a meaningless objective? If your answer is yes, I worry for you.

The real question here is does anyone who comes up with half-assed "solutions" to any given problem actually bother to put more than a few seconds rampart thought into it before they sperg all over the forums with meaningless crap that doesn't actually benefit anyone, ever.

As a final note, what the hell is wrong with a meaningless accompishment anyway? There are literally thousands of them littering almost all the top games being played right now. Here's a hint. EVERYTHING in a video game is a meaningless accomplishment, it just depends on your perspective.
